questions.question: What does SIMD stand for?
questions.explanation: SIMD executes one instruction on multiple data elements simultaneously for parallel processing.

questions.question: What does MIMD stand for?
questions.explanation: MIMD allows different processors to execute different instructions on different data independently.

questions.question: What is a processor with multiple independent cores called?
questions.explanation: A multicore processor integrates two or more independent processing units on a single chip.

questions.question: What is the smallest unit of execution in a program?
questions.explanation: A thread is the basic unit of CPU utilization that can be scheduled and executed independently.

questions.question: What does GPU stand for?
questions.explanation: GPU is a specialized processor designed for parallel processing of graphics and computational tasks.

questions.question: What is executing multiple threads at the same time called?
questions.explanation: Multithreading allows a processor to execute multiple threads concurrently for improved performance.

questions.question: What type of parallelism applies the same operation to multiple data?
questions.explanation: Data parallelism distributes data across multiple processors that perform the same operation.

questions.question: What type of parallelism executes different tasks simultaneously?
questions.explanation: Task parallelism divides a program into different concurrent tasks executed on separate processors.

questions.question: What measures performance improvement from parallel execution?
questions.explanation: Speedup is the ratio of sequential execution time to parallel execution time.

questions.question: What is the ratio of sequential time to parallel time called?
questions.explanation: Speedup is the ratio of sequential execution time to parallel execution time, measuring performance improvement.
